content.thinking: Now I have a clear picture of the project. Let me also check if there's a scene.js and AIEngine.js to understand how characters work, so I can show character status in the dashboard.
Now I have a good understanding of the codebase. Let me also check the Engine.js to understand how sim time and character management works.

Now I have all the information I need to build the debug dashboard. Let me plan what needs to be done:

1. Create `debug.html` â€” standalone page with:
   - Dark theme dashboard
   - Header with title and sim clock
   - Controls (Play/Pause, Speed, Reset)
   - Object cards grid (10 objects)
   - Character cards (3 characters: Maple/Sol/Nyx)
   - Event log

2. Modify `index.html` â€” add Debug button that opens an overlay panel

Key insights from reading the code:
- `ObjectEngine` and `OBJECT_DEFS` are exported from `src/objects.js`


- The engine has `tick(deltaMs)`, `interact(objectId, action)`, `getAll()`, and `getById(id)` methods
- `ObjectInstance` tracks `id`, `name`, `state`, `autoTimer`, `states`, and `interactMs`
- Characters store `name`, `label`, position (`tx`, `ty`), `action`, `facing`, `mood`, `energy`, `interactTarget`, and `targetObjectId`
- `SimulationEngine` is exported from `Engine.js` rather than `objects.js`

For `debug.html`, I'll import the engine and object definitions to display real-time state updates.

I'm realizing I can actually use the real `SimulationEngine` and `Character` classes since sprites and labels are optionalâ€”they just get set to null if not provided, and the update logic handles that gracefully. The only requirement is passing a walkable grid to the engine, which I can create as a simple stub for the debug view. Building the HTML structure...

Now I'm setting up the imports for the simulation and character systems, then planning the display layout to show character stats like name, action, position, and mood, plus object information including state and properties.

I'm working out a color-coding system for object states where idle states are green, active states like cooking or brewing are yellow, completed states are blue, and relaxing states are purple, then I'll use a simple heuristic based on the state name to assign the right colors.

For the timer progress bar, I need to calculate the remaining time by comparing the current countdown against the total duration from the auto_next configuration. For transitions, I'll check what actions are available on the current state and wire up clicks to trigger the engine's interact method. I also need to hook into the event system to capture and display what's happening in the log.

Setting up the core simulation loop...

I need to track previous states so I can show the transition from one state to another when events occur. I'll maintain a map that stores each object's state before the tick, then compare it against what the engine returns to capture the full before-and-after picture for the event log. I need to import the simulation classes that don't depend on Phaser, then build out the debug dashboard with a tick loop and DOM rendering for both objects and characters showing their current state, position, and interactions.

Writing debug dashboard styles... Still writing styles... Still writing styles... Still writing styles... Still writing styles... Still writing styles... Building the control panel and layout structure... Setting up character configurations...

Now I'm defining the grid dimensions and building a walkable area that constrains movement to the interior of the scene, then initializing the simulation engine with that grid.

Setting up the character system by instantiating each character from the config and registering them with the engine, then establishing state tracking for the simulation including pause controls, speed adjustment, and an event log to monitor state changes across all objects. Setting up speed controls and the reset button...

Now I'm adding a helper function to handle interactions between objects, logging state changes as they occur, and I'm starting to define a function for rendering state badges.

Building the DOM rendering... Building the card content... Building character cards... Building the character display... Writing the tick loop...

I'm realizing there's an issue with how the interact handler worksâ€”when I call `handleInteract`, it directly invokes `simEngine.objectEngine.interact()`, but that bypasses the state change detection I've set up in the update loop. Since `simEngine.update()` handles both ticking and state diffing, I need to make sure interactions also trigger that same update mechanism so the log entries get captured properly. affect character behavior or speech. For the debug dashboard this is fine.

Let me also reconsider the approach for detecting state changes. The issue is:
- `simEngine.update(deltaMs)` calls `objectEngine.tick(deltaMs)` internally
- `objectEngine.tick()` returns events with `{objectId, state, emoji, auto}`
- But I can't intercept these from `simEngine.update()`

So I should track states by diffing before/after `simEngine.update()`.

Actually this is fine. My approach is:
1. Before tick: save all current states
2. Call simEngine.update()
3. After tick: compare states, log any changes

This is what I'm doing in the tick function. Let me clean up the redundant `prevStates` map and just use the before/after comparison.

When the user clicks "Use" on an object, I'm calling `simEngine.objectEngine.interact()` directly, which bypasses character behavior but changes the object state. The tricky part is that the next `simEngine.update()` might also try to interact with that same object if a character is attempting it, potentially causing double-interactionsâ€”though for debugging purposes this is acceptable. I need to be careful with the reset functionality to ensure it properly reinitializes object states.

For the debug panel UI, I'm planning to add a fixed "Debug" button in the top-right corner that toggles an overlay panel sliding in from the right, displaying all objects with their current states and interactive "Use" buttons for each one.

The tricky part is that the Phaser game and the HTML overlay live in different scopes, so I need to expose the game engine to the window object so the overlay can access and display the same state. I'll set `window._gameEngine` from the scene initialization so both contexts can reference it. I'll expose the game engine on the window object in the scene's create method, then build out the debug interface in index.html with a toggle button and sidebar panel that reads from that exposed engine to display object states and use buttons.

Setting up the debug panel loop...

Now I'm working through the timer bar logic for the progress visualization. The timer counts down from the total duration, so I need to calculate the elapsed percentage as `1 - (currentTimer / totalMs)` to show progress from 0% at the start to 100% when time runs out. There's a timing edge case when the state just changed that I need to handle carefully. The CSS transition won't work since we're rebuilding the entire innerHTML each frame, so I need to switch to targeted DOM updates insteadâ€”creating the cards once and only updating the values that change. I'm restructuring to initialize the object cards...

Building the card markup... Updating the card styling and rebuilding the interaction buttons whenever the state changes, then calculating the timer progress percentage based on how much time remains in the auto-transition countdown. I need to expose the SimulationEngine on the window object so the overlay can access it, then build a simpler version of the dashboard that shows just the object name, state badge, and transition buttons without the timer bars or event log.

Now I'm thinking through the CSS animation for the timer barsâ€”a 0.5-second transition might be too slow if we're updating every frame, so I need to figure out how frequent updates should be to keep the animation smooth without being jarring. out any jitter in the timer. Now I need to finalize the implementationâ€”I'll handle the `_resetAutoTimer` call on ObjectInstance by accessing it through `engine.getById()`, and for the index.html overlay, I'll add the HTML directly since the Phaser game initializes after the DOM loads and exposes `window._gameEngine`. My plan is to create a debug.html file with a standalone dashboard that imports the necessary engine classes and runs a headless simulation with rAF updates for smooth DOM rendering.

For index.html, I'll add CSS styling for the debug overlay, a toggle button in the top-right corner, and JavaScript that polls `window._gameEngine` to update the panel. I also need to modify src/scene.js to expose the engine via `window._gameEngine` in the create method.

Wait, I should double-check what "same object state info" means in the requirementsâ€”it could refer to the game engine's actual state, which would require exposing the engine, or it could just mean the same type of information displayed differently.

I'll go with exposing the actual engine state since that's simpler and more useful. The "Use" buttons in the overlay will call `window._gameEngine.objectEngine.interact(id, action)` to trigger interactions directly in the game.

Let me check the memory file structure first to see if there's anything relevant I should know about.

file.content:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8" />
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />
  <title>AI Aquarium â€” Maple's CafÃ©</title>
  <style>
    * { margin: 0; padding: 0; box-sizing: border-box; }
    html, body { width: 100%; height: 100%; background: #1a1a2e; overflow: hidden; }
    canvas { image-rendering: pixelated; image-rendering: crisp-edges; display: block; }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/phaser@3.88.2/dist/phaser.min.js"></script>
<script type="module">
import { CafeScene } from './src/scene.js?v=14';
new Phaser.Game({
  type: Phaser.AUTO,
  width: 912, height: 642,
  backgroundColor: '#1a1a2e',
  scale: { mode: Phaser.Scale.FIT, autoCenter: Phaser.Scale.CENTER_BOTH },
  render: { antialias: false, pixelArt: true },
  scene: CafeScene,
});
</script>
</body>
</html>

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8" />
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />
  <title>AI Aquarium â€” Maple's CafÃ©</title>
  <style>
    * { margin: 0; padding: 0; box-sizing: border-box; }
    html, body { width: 100%; height: 100%; background: #1a1a2e; overflow: hidden; }
    canvas { image-rendering: pixelated; image-rendering: crisp-edges; display: block; }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/phaser@3.88.2/dist/phaser.min.js"></script>
<script type="module">
import { CafeScene } from './src/scene.js?v=14';
new Phaser.Game({
  type: Phaser.AUTO,
  width: 912, height: 642,
  backgroundColor: '#1a1a2e',
  scale: { mode: Phaser.Scale.FIT, autoCenter: Phaser.Scale.CENTER_BOTH },
  render: { antialias: false, pixelArt: true },
  scene: CafeScene,
});
</script>
</body>
</html>

input.command:
git add debug.html index.html src/scene.js && git commit -m "$(cat <<'EOF'
feat: add debug dashboard panel with object state controls (FRG-134)

- debug.html: standalone full-page dashboard with object cards, character
  cards, timer progress bars, interactive Use buttons, event log, and
  Play/Pause/Speed/Reset controls; runs its own SimulationEngine + Characters
- index.html: Debug toggle button (top-right corner) opens a 280px overlay
  panel showing live object states with Use buttons and a link to debug.html;
  bumped scene.js cache-bust version to v15
- src/scene.js: expose this.engine on window._gameEngine after create() so
  the overlay panel can read live game state

Co-Authored-By: Claude Sonnet 4.6 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)"

newTodos.content: Add Debug overlay panel to index.html
newTodos.activeForm: Adding Debug overlay panel to index.html

newTodos.content: Commit and push
newTodos.activeForm: Committing and pushing

content.text:
## Status
DONE

## What Changed
- **`debug.html`** (new): Standalone full-page dashboard with dark theme â€” object cards grid (state badge, timer progress bar, Use buttons), 3 character cards (action/position/facing/target/mood/energy stat bars), scrollable event log with fromâ†’to transitions color-coded auto/interaction, Play/Pause/Speed/Reset controls, live sim clock. Imports `ObjectEngine`, `OBJECT_DEFS`, `SimulationEngine`, `Character` and runs a headless simulation (no sprites).
- **`index.html`**: Added "Debug" toggle button (fixed top-right) that opens a 280px overlay panel showing live object states with state badges, timer progress bars, and Use buttons. Footer links to `debug.html`. Bumped scene cache-bust version to v15.
- **`src/scene.js`**: Added `window._gameEngine = this.engine;` in `create()` so the overlay reads the actual running game state rather than a separate instance.

## Key Decisions
- Overlay panel reads from `window._gameEngine` (live game engine) via polling rAF loop; interactions call `objectEngine.interact()` directly, affecting the actual Phaser simulation.
- `debug.html` runs its own `SimulationEngine` + headless `Character` instances (null sprites work fine since `Character.update()` guards all sprite access), so it's fully independent from Phaser.
- Used targeted DOM updates (not innerHTML rebuild per frame) so CSS `transition: width 0.1s ease-out` on timer fill bars works smoothly.

## PR / Branch
- Pushed directly to `master` â€” commit `3d3aa58`

## Status
DONE

## What Changed
- **`debug.html`** (new): Standalone full-page dashboard with dark theme â€” object cards grid (state badge, timer progress bar, Use buttons), 3 character cards (action/position/facing/target/mood/energy stat bars), scrollable event log with fromâ†’to transitions color-coded auto/interaction, Play/Pause/Speed/Reset controls, live sim clock. Imports `ObjectEngine`, `OBJECT_DEFS`, `SimulationEngine`, `Character` and runs a headless simulation (no sprites).
- **`index.html`**: Added "Debug" toggle button (fixed top-right) that opens a 280px overlay panel showing live object states with state badges, timer progress bars, and Use buttons. Footer links to `debug.html`. Bumped scene cache-bust version to v15.
- **`src/scene.js`**: Added `window._gameEngine = this.engine;` in `create()` so the overlay reads the actual running game state rather than a separate instance.

## Key Decisions
- Overlay panel reads from `window._gameEngine` (live game engine) via polling rAF loop; interactions call `objectEngine.interact()` directly, affecting the actual Phaser simulation.
- `debug.html` runs its own `SimulationEngine` + headless `Character` instances (null sprites work fine since `Character.update()` guards all sprite access), so it's fully independent from Phaser.
- Used targeted DOM updates (not innerHTML rebuild per frame) so CSS `transition: width 0.1s ease-out` on timer fill bars works smoothly.

## PR / Branch
